name: Kepler-51
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-51 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-51 is a star with 1.04 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.94 times its radius. It is located 2614.9883456 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 0.3 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-51 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-51 system

Kepler-51 b

Kepler-51 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-51 b is 2.1 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-51 b is 7.1 that of Earth. At 2.1 Earth masses, Kepler-51 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-51 c

Kepler-51 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-51 c is 4 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-51 c is 9 that of Earth. At 4 Earth masses, Kepler-51 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-51 d

Kepler-51 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-51 d is 7.6 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-51 d is 9.7 that of Earth. At 7.6 Earth masses, Kepler-51 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-51, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
